those different geographies and so Germany's the the great example because German laws are so specific about what
can happen with their citizens data and so when you want to provide a service that is globally available and appears
to have the same information and the same capabilities everywhere you have to think about how you do that while at the
same time protecting all those individual laws about where things live on disk and then later being able to
prove through audit uh that you actually maintain those laws and and that's something that our architecture is
really uniquely suited to be able to support okay
um tell us about what there is in that specific architecture that is there to help that sure so the architecture is
built around uh a peer-to-peer model so there's complete Independence there's no master of anything there's no central
point of coordination those peers are running in one of two models they're running either in memory or they're
focused on disk the in memory peers are where we're having SQL clients connect to the system driving transactions uh
where we're enforcing kind of all the consistency and atomicity rules um but then we think about data durability as a
separate concern and so we're really not optimized uh to worry about iops on disk
per se uh we're also not really concerned about where the data lives on disk relative to where you can actually
drive transactions and so for us it's much more about how do you bring things into caches very efficiently have these
peers work together well and then separately you worry about where the data may live in one or more locations on
disk okay so in in a multi- region model what are your what are your biggest

trying to simplify the tools simplify the apis uh make that easy to work with
